title: 111_hr2667
content: The "Early Support for Families Act" establishes grants for quality home visitation programs for families with young children and expecting families under the Social Security Act. The section aims to enhance child well-being by supporting quality home visitation programs for families with young children and expecting families. States seeking grants must submit applications detailing the programs, their intended outcomes, and evidence of effectiveness. The curr_chunk discusses the results of a statewide needs assessment for home visitation programs for families with young children. It includes information on program quality, funding sources, gaps in services, and training activities. The curr_chunk outlines assurances from the State for supporting home visitation programs, including prioritizing communities in high need, reserving funds for training and technical assistance, and supporting programs for low-income families and child maltreatment. The State must provide assurances for supporting home visitation programs, including prioritizing high-need communities, reserving funds for training and technical assistance, promoting coordination with other services, providing referrals when appropriate, complying with requirements, and cooperating with evaluations. Additionally, the Secretary may require other information. The Secretary may require other information. Allotments are made to Indian tribes and states based on poverty line income ratios. The Secretary allots funds to States based on poverty line income ratios for children. States must meet certain requirements to receive funding. Unused funds can be reallocated to other States. The Secretary allots funds to States based on poverty line income ratios for children. States must meet requirements to receive funding, with unused funds available for reallocation. States must maintain a certain level of expenditure for home visitation programs to qualify for funding. The Secretary will make grants to eligible States. The Secretary will make a grant to each State meeting requirements for a fiscal year, based on eligible expenditures and allotted amounts. The reimbursable percentage varies by fiscal year. The Secretary will make grants to States based on eligible expenditures for voluntary home visitation programs for families with young children. The reimbursable percentage varies by fiscal year, starting at 85% in 2010 and decreasing to 75% in 2012 and beyond. The Secretary will make grants to States for voluntary home visitation programs for families with young children. Programs must demonstrate positive effects on child and parenting outcomes, employ well-trained staff, and establish linkages to community resources. Priority funding is given to programs with strong evidence. Priority funding is given to programs with the strongest evidence of effectiveness in home visitation, with expenditures exceeding a certain percentage not considered eligible. The applicable percentage for fiscal years 2010 to 2014 ranges from 60% to 40%. States receiving grants under this section cannot use other federal funds for their share of costs. The Secretary has the authority to waive or modify provisions of this section. The Secretary has the authority to waive or modify provisions of this section for Indian tribes if it would impose an undue burden. States receiving grants must submit annual reports on their progress in addressing the purposes of the section. The State must submit annual reports on the progress made in delivering services, program characteristics, provider qualifications, recipient demographics, and program costs. The evaluation of home visitation programs funded under this section includes assessing program costs, outcomes for recipients, training provided for implementation, and monitoring methods to ensure program fidelity. An independent evaluation will be conducted to determine the effectiveness of these programs. The evaluation of home visitation programs funded under this section will assess their impact on child and parent outcomes, including child maltreatment, health, development, school readiness, and community service links. It will also examine the effectiveness of these programs on different populations. Within 2 years, an interim report on the evaluation will be submitted to Congress. The Secretary shall submit an interim report to Congress within 2 years on the evaluation of home visitation programs. Additionally, a final report must be submitted within 4 years. Annual reports to Congress on program activities, high need communities targeted, service delivery models, and program characteristics are also required. The interim and final reports to Congress on the evaluation of home visitation programs must include information on service delivery models, program characteristics, outcomes, research-based activities, training provided, and annual costs of implementation. The annual costs of implementing home visitation programs, indicators for monitoring program implementation, and reservations of funds for evaluation, training, technical assistance, and grants to Indian tribes. The Secretary is appropriated funds for grants to Indian tribes under this section, with specific amounts allocated for fiscal years 2010 to 2014. Indian tribes are treated as states in this section.
